comments.commentBody: Nice try, but won't convince anyone other than die hard Modi supporters. The question asked was simple and the answer was direct. The question was whether Modi regretted anything about the massacre of thousands of people that happened under his watch in 2002? Modi replied he regretted the fact that he didn't manage the media better. It is a chilling answer. Of course, if you don't want to go by that, you can go by the numerous hate speeches that Modi made against Muslims after 2002. Today Modi might want to distance himself from Hindu extremist leaders, but what he has been saying about Muslims in the past has been no different than the Hindu extremist leaders. (Hum paanch, hamara pachhis, anyone?). Any decent human being (whatever his or her political views) should be worried that extremist Hindu organizations in India like VHP/Bajrang Dal and RSS has millions of adherents. I have seen Hindu extremists calmly defending the murder of thousands including innocent women and children. It is high time the world takes note of this fascist movement in the worlds largest democracy.

It was supposed to be funny, but the part about Modi telling Celia Dugger that he should have managed the media better was definitely a low pot shot at Modi. I bet Modi's comment to Celia Dugger was sarcastic, because he has for long complained that all journalists who talk to him wanted to discuss the Govt response to the riots. Any leader would be absolutely frustrated with constantly being poked on the same subject. Mr Oliver did a dis-service to his show by including that clip - it was most certainly partisan and a low shot.
@E.T.Bass: The incremental costs are minimal compared to the billions wasted on unnecessary military hardware built in influential congressional districts and other sacred hogs like sugar subsidies.

" .. The incremental costs are minimal .."

Then show everyone the numbers. Thank you.

Does the "Victims protection act of 2014" protect Victims of false accusation by providing for stiff criminal penalties for those found to be falsely accusing others of sex crimes? False accusations of sex crimes are quite common, being used among other things as a "nuclear bomb" option in divorce cases to automatically win custody of the children, no questions asked, yet prosecutions are exceedingly rare. The deck is already severely stacked in favor of accusers and against the accused by the improper assumption that all accusers are "victims" that causes their identity to be protected, while the name of the accused, who may or may not be guilty, is dragged through the mud. Hopefully this "Victims" protection act you laud is designed to protect all victims involved when there is an accusation of sexual misconduct, whether the victim is the accuser or the accusee. I suspect however that the act is presuming that the accuser in any given case is identical to the "Victim" which is a highly improper assumption for a nation supposedly based on principles of legal fairness dating back to the magna carta, including the right to an impartial and fair trial, and the right to not be presumed guilty without having been convicted based on evidence.

The Victims Protection Act of 2014 was passed by 97 members of the US Senate in March, and was immediately passed onto the House, where it remains languishing without action. Despite the fact that The Pentagon has estimated that as many as 26,000 military members may have been sexually assaulted in 2012, based on an anonymous survey, our congress still has not passed into law basic improvements in military responses to sexual assaults.

Now, today, after carefully considered, sane and modest proposals contained in the White House Task Force’s report are revealed, we learn that higher education institutions are already mounting opposition to a key recommendation – anonymous campus climate surveys. "I will say colleges are concerned about additional requirements, whether they be by regulation or legislation," said Ada Meloy, general counsel for the American Council of Education, which lobbies on behalf of 1,200 higher education institutions.” (source: Huffington Post, Proposal To Require Campus Climate Surveys On Sexual Assault Faces Quick Opposition, 4/29/14).

Kudos to the brave survivors and their allies, both in the military and on college campuses, who began this fight and brought it to national attention and to the political arena. The accomplishments are huge, but the movement cannot rest, for there still is a long fight ahead of us. It appears that in the USA, there is a status quo of stubborn, callous resistance to improving the response to sexual assault survivors.

I do feel sympathy for WV and Appalachia in general. Being from Indiana, a manufacturing giant in the day, I can tell the residents of those states a very stern thing: you either adapt, or you regress into a memory. My state is still way too dependent upon manufacturing, but we are changing, not because we want to, but because technology has left us with no choice. I live in a triangle of medium-sized towns that used to employ more than 35,000 people directly in the auto industry, and many more in jobs allied with that industry. How many of those jobs are left now? A handful, maybe a thousand, and they are low-wage at that. We resisted these changes at first, didn't want to change, but that change was inevitable. Our young people are getting better educations now and moving on, sometimes just moving. We are getting new jobs, but it is taking time. My advice: accept the inevitable and adapt. If training programs are available through either the state or the fed, take advantage... don't waste time on false pride. Elect politicians that tell you the truth, that those jobs are gone, boys, and they ain't coming back, and then ride herd on those politicians to be bipartisan enough to work both sides of the aisle for your benefit. There is no reason Appalachia should be so dependent on coal, just as there is no reason my state should still be totally dependent upon manufacturing. This is a sad truth, but the facts have been apparent for years. We all have been delaying inevitability
A pithy, sharp and fun comment.  Thanks.

The only "untouchable" bank seems to be Goldman Sachs. It really stands alone among all large institutions by the lack of attention that the Feds seem to pay to GS' alleged improprieties. That alone should be cause for question and concern. Especially when the revolving door between GS and the federal government raises so many eyebrows.

I thought exactly the same thing. Why is The Times repeating the spin? Unless actual people face prison time, the moral hazard issue will remain front and center. Paying fines is just the cost of doing business for these criminal racketeering cartels.
Where can I get that bumper sticker?

Why is the Times echoing the feds' spin on this story? The government is still trying to make it look like they're punishing the banks, but without really hurting them. Fines are simply a cost of doing business. The companies will extract the funds from their customers and write them off on their tax returns. Until the authorities either start punishing the individuals responsible or seriously impairing the companies' ability to do business, the whole process will continue to be a charade. If corporations want the rights of individuals, let them accept the consequences individuals face when they break the law. As the bumper sticker says, "I'll believe corporations are people when Texas executes one."

It did not take long Maureen for you to shift gears to an all out no holds barred criticism of President Obama dealing with whining, whiffing. and being thin skinned. As for the chatterers, good for you; with fair weather friends like them, along with the Democrats involved in the mid term election on the run from any association with the President, which you did not mention, he has a great deal to worry about on the domestic front.

"The problems roiling the world now are brutally hard"; particularly that the European members of NATO declined to agree to follow the US lead in the territorial spat with Russia, since trade and the comfort of Gazprom were more important to Chancellor Merkel, the leader of the EU, than any concern for Ukraine.

I must disagree with "don't you know that we're speeched out?" The speech that must be delivered to the American people, and is way overdue, must deal with the precise details of the TPP trade deal and how it will affect the working class, the middle class, consumers and small business in the US. We the people have been kept in the dark, yet again, as we were in the case of NAFTA, of how a secret trade pact will affect us, our future, and the future of our children and grandchildren.

The issue which is frustrating has little to do with personality traits or style; it is about leadership. My firm belief that the President of the US is required to be the leader of the nation remains unfulfilled. It is past time to lead from the front.
Agreed. What are the units of value and how many do I recieve or deduct for each act. Ben Franklins philandering was obviously not such a negative value as he had affairs beyond count

In "A History of the Modern Fact," historian Mary Poovey shows that in Renaissance Florence, accounting books weren't expected to be truthful. Any intelligent businessperson would keep many facts about his business secret. The point of balancing accounts was to show his skill in arithmetic -- even if it meant adding in arbitrary numbers (visible in the book's illustrations) to make the two sides balance. It was careful skill in arithmetic, not the transparency of records, that was supposed to encourage your trust in the merchant.

Even more to the point, there is a scene in James Joyce's Ulysses where a priest gives a sermon about a moral "reckoning of accounts," and reassuringly tells his audience that they should try to make their accounts balance. Joyce's joke was that in that case, the bad will exactly balance the good -- instead of there being an excess of good.

I'm with Joyce. Understanding accounting may be helpful for detecting financial fraud. But to hang more moral significance onto it is rather wrong-headed.

When investors or partners are harmful to the effort, they have to go. You will see this stuff happen in any business when one person decides to play a longtime little game with everyone else.

The housing record on this owner is indicative of his inability to discipline himself. He was fined over 2 million for Fair Housing law violations? That costs everybody else. This guy is simply irresponsible and irrational.
His history speaks for itself.

Any partners of his would be relieved to have him gone. He would continue to lose everybody else income and impact future careers. Fans pay for tickets and deserve to be treated with respect. They have been treated as fools while this person offends everyone. Why hand over cash to teams with owners like this?

I am sorry it took this long to see this removal. Like tax dodger and self-proclaimed "patriot" Cliven Bundy, the incompetence, the complete lack of respect for anyone else and the contempt shown for basic decency speaks louder than anything else.

I think most of us are better people than this. At least, I hope so.

Was he good as a team owner? Otherwise, his personal preferences and opinions – racial, ethnic, sexual, religious, whatever – are his own and nobody's business unless he acts bigotedly upon them. Was he biased or fair in his treatment of his players.

I've heard the recording released by TMZ where Sterling explains his position in a PRIVATE CONVERSATION WITH HIS MISTRESS – who must've set him up, possibly at TMZ's urging – during a personal argument. His tone is pleading, not in the least aggressive or violent. She appears to deliberately goad him on.
http://extramustard.si.com/2014/04/26/clippers-donald-sterling-racist-co...

I don't condone racism but I do support Freedom of Speech (and thought), ESPECIALLY PRIVATE SPEECH, even if hateful.

"In the dystopian novel 1984 by George Orwell, THOUGHTCRIME is the criminal act of holding unspoken beliefs or doubts that oppose or question the ruling party. In the novel, the government attempts to control not only the speech and actions, but also the thoughts of its subjects. Unacceptable thought is known as CRIMETHINK. The THOUGHT POLICE ('thinkpol') are the secret police whose job it is to uncover and punish thoughtcrime. The term 'Thought Police', by extension, has come to refer to real or perceived ENFORCEMENT OF IDEOLOGICAL CORRECTNESS."~ georgeorwellnovels.com

Even hateful speech is constitutionally protected.

Unfortunately, Mr. Sterling has a case. See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snyder_v._Phelps

Ah, Drakes. Once a week, my grandmother would show up - she always brought something. Yodels, even the down-sizing of Devil Dogs, Funny Bones, and nirvana - Ring Dings.

Alas, you can't buy 'em west of the Mississippi. Which is why we do a Drakes 'run' every time we go east. I feel bad for Californians who never grew up with sublime pleasures of peeling the chocolate layer off a Ring Ding, ingesting the creme filling, and then, sated, smoothing out the foil wrapper.

as  a kid, i loved Ring Dings -- but i remember when they were just *one* cake, with a crisp dark chocolate (real chocolate) coating, moist cake and lots of whatever that creme filling was.  in later years, there were two ring dings, the chocolate became whatever that brown smeary stuff is that passes for chocolate nowdays, and the cake was stiff and dry.  in some ways, i'm glad -- at least i'm not tempted by them in their boxes in the supermarket.  and i make a killer chocolate cake with a genache icing and the whipped cream center.

Good for you, Mark, for succumbing to bagels, lox and cream cheese. Me, I prefer my bagels thickly buttered, as did Ed Koch, before adding lox.

Other comfort foods from my childhood: a boiled chicken lobster with drawn butter, a tongue sandwich with Russian dressing, my grandmother's noodles with sour cream and her meatloaf with an egg roasted in the middle.

As for childhood packaged food pleasures: Ring Dings and Yodels from Drake's Cakes; Mallomars; Dairy Queen; Schrafft's ice cream.

Where were you in 1976, NIgel? Many of us were here, renting apartments, shopping at Macys and Saks, paying to go to the ballet, the theater, museums, and, yes, saving money. At a time when many people wouldn't even venture to visit New York City, much less live here, we were living here and investing here -- even if you don't believe we "helped make the city what it is."

In my rental building the only people with cars (usually great big SUVs) and vacation homes are the 20-something tenants, often subsidized by their parents back home in places like Texas and Colorado.

At one point all apartments in buildings with more than four units were stabilized. So even if you wanted an unstabilized apartment, you couldn't have gotten one. Simply by virtue of staying in the same place for a long time many people are in stabilized apartments.

Ellienyc: Houston Grand Opera. Theater Under the Stars. Alley Theater. Houston Symphony. Houston Ballet. Museum of Fine Arts Houston. Menil Collection. True, they're not as venerable as their New York a Counterparts, but in many cases tickets are far less expensive, and you'll cut your rent in half by living here instead of New York City.
.
(Oh, and if you're worried about being sick in your old age, there are few places better than our Medical Center to take care of you.)

I don't see Buddhism as a religion or as atheistic.  Religions (and atheists) qualify, or define themselves. A practitioner of Buddhism suspends qualification or identification.  Buddhism is a practice that suspends the action of belief, even in god or not god. Buddhism is not in opposition to religion or in belief of it.  I think the constant reference of people to Buddhism as a religion (or not a religion) is very un-Buddhist-like.  Such as this comment . .

Read "A Mathematician's Lament" by Paul Lockart http://www.maa.org/sites/default/files/pdf/devlin/LockhartsLament.pdf Lockart, a mathematician and teacher details your point that there is no practical application of having yearlong courses in Trigonometry and other advanced mathematics for all students. Estimation, probability, spatial relations, and fluency with numbers are all everyday applications that should be embedded in all course content, and is, in many schools. The nonsense of so many adults claiming to be "bad" at Math is really code for "I hated math classes in school.

Double-entery bookkeeping is a canard. Why don't we just put as much emphasis on teaching a better understanding of interest rates in our schools as we do on square roots, trigonometry, and geometry?  Nearly every American will be faced with many important decisions dependent on interest rates. How many people really need to know how to calculate a square root or calculate the sine of an angle? Yet, what are we devoting entire courses to in our schools: trigonometry and geometry rather than interest rates and other useful financial calculations. In the era when nearly everyone has ready access to simple budgeting programs, most people don't need to understand double-entry accounting. But everyone should know how to calculate percentages and understand how a car loan or home mortgage is calculated.

I understand the impact on an economy if a large bank goes under and the need for Federal caution in prosecuting. But if all the individuals responsible were charged to the limit, sent to jail and had to give up their fortunes; the banks were fined heavily enough that they lost the profit that allows them to pay these criminals, but were still able to continue doing business; and focused, heavy policing was introduced so the threat of future punishment was real, the banking culture would change pretty fast.

But I think this is a great first step. I hope it's causing many sleepless nights. I wonder how much money was accumulated by crooked or irresponsible bank execs. Imagine if they had to give it all up, every cent of it, and that money was paid out to individuals who were hurt by the banking crisis. Now that would be trickle down in action.
Andy --- Do not forget the schools all the way from about Crescent City north up to about Port Hardy.

They'll find a way. They already export a certain amount, though I don't have numbers; this is primarily just from picking things up from articles/podcasts/news programs (both conservative and liberal.)

Natural gas will be next despite the fact that it is in abundant supply.

Instead in order to derive 20% of our electricity from wind we will be building 2,000 wind farms the size of the 200,000 acre facility in Roscoe, Texas. Rosco is the nations largest wind farm. That equates to 400 million acres of land area.

Is Thomas more Republican than Ginsberg is a Democrat?  Kudos!  What an interesting, new way to suggest we get back to political division and name calling, rather than improving the quality of the air we all breathe!
Thomas' wife works for the Koch's.  He wouldn't recognize a conflict of interest even if he were awake during sessions.
Is Thomas more Republican than Ginsburg is Democrat.  No, but the comparison compels mention of meanness, where Thomas and Scalia excel.
Would someone remind Justice Thomas that he has to occasionally think through a case rather than just vote along the GOP line?  We know that Scalia is a demagogue but at least he is rational.

Forgive me for my cynicism,  but unless I see *actual* human beings (no high speed trading computers, please) in handcuffs doing a perp walk, I will view this is nothing more than an election year stunt.

Your PAL,

Bru

Your argument is convenient for corporations - gain the benefits of collaborative power, but not suffer the consequences of its collective actions.

People within a corporation can of course participate in politics as individuals, but if they want rights as a collective, they should accept the responsibilities as a collective. If one person screws up, they all go down - just like with any team.

JP Morgan and nearly all Wall St Banks should be put out of business for criminal activity. if employees suffer as a result, too bad - maybe next time they'll think twice about joining a criminal enterprise.

The idea of charging a corporation with a crime is stupid. Charging the officer, employees, shareholders, directors -- that makes sense.

Corporations are legal persons -- but not legal people. They are merely a way that people group together to act together. A group, as such, is a concept -- not someone who can be imprisoned. Charge the individuals, not the concept of an organization.

The same entity confusion plagues people who argue that corporations should not have right to free speech. Of course they should not -- because it's not the corporation that has a right to free speech -- it is the people who are the shareholders, directors, officers, and shareholders.

People have free speech rights and people can commit crimes. They are the ones who deserve freedom and who deserve to be punished when they violate the law.
